ing the nature of evolution of the Universe. The former one tells us the expansion rate of the Universe today while the latter one characterizes the accelerating :formula: or decel- erating :formula: nature of the Universe. In the recent past, there have been numerous attempts to estimate the value of :formula: Freedman et al. (2001) used the Hubble Space Tele- scope (HST) observations of Cepheid variable to estimate a value of :formula: km :formula: An observational determination of the Hubble constant obtained by Suyu et al. (2010) based upon measurements of gravitational lens- ing by using the HST yielded a value of :formula: ] :formula: WMAP seven-year results gave an estimate of :formula: based on WMAP data alone, and an estimate of :formula: km :formula: based on WMAP data with Gaussian priors corresponding to earlier estimates from other studies (Jarosik et al. 2011). A recent estimate of the Hubble constant, which used a new infrared camera on the HST to measure the distance and redshift for a collection of astronomical objects, gives a value of :formula: (Riess et al. 2011). An alter- native probe using data from galactic clusters gave a value of :formula: (Beutler et al. 2011).
In this paper, we show that the power-law cosmology essentially depends on the parameters :formula: and :formula: We intend to find the observational constraints on the power-law cos- mology parameters using the recent observational data from :formula: and supernova observations. We also intend to test the power-law cosmology with primordial nucleosynthesis. The paper is organized as follows: The basic equations of power- law cosmology are introduced in Section 2. Section 3 deals with the constraints on the parameters :formula: and :formula: from the latest :formula: data while Section 4 is devoted to find the con- straints using Union2 compilation of 557 SNe Ia data points. In Section 5, we perform the joint test using :formula: and SNe Ia data. Section 6 deals with the constraints on power-law cosmology from primordial nucleosynthesis while Section 7 is devoted to study the statefinders in power-law cosmology. In the last Section, we summarize the main results of the paper.

We study a general class of power-law cosmology described by the dimensionless scale factor

3 CONSTRAINTS FROM OBSERVATIONAL :formula: DATA
Simon, Verde & Jimenez (2005) determined nine :formula: data points in the range :formula: by using the differential ages of passively evolving galaxies determined from the Gemini Deep Deep Survey and archival data. Recently, :formula: data at 11 different redshifts based on the differential ages of red- envelope galaxies were reported by Stern et al. (2010) while 3 more :formula: data points were obtained by Gaztanaga, Cabre & Hui (2009). The newly :formula: data points have been used to constrain parameters of various cosmological models (Yang & Zhang 2010; Cao, Zhu & Liang 2011; Chen & Ratra 2011; Paul, Thakur & Ghose 2010, 2011). Here, we use 13 obser- vational :formula: data points given in Table 1 of the paper by Chen & Ratra (2011) and :formula: estimated in the work by Riess et al. (2011). @ 2012 RAS, MNRAS 422, 2532-2538
2535
Constraints on power-law cosmology
collision of neutrons and protons is rapidly photodissoci- ated by the cosmic background photons. This causes very low abundance of :formula: and thus heavier nuclei are not formed at this epoch. Thus nucleosynthesis is delayed by this "pho- todissociation bottleneck". However, when the universe is ~ 3 minutes old, the temperature falls below ~ 80 keV, the deuterium bottleneck is broken. At this stage the nuclear reactions quickly burn out the remaining free neutrons into 4He and leave trace amounts of D, 3He and :formula: (Walker et al. 1991). A viable cosmological model must mimic the above scenario for proper synthesis of the light elements in the early Universe. In the following, we test the power-law cosmological model for primordial nucleosynthesis.
In power-law cosmology the scale factor :formula: and the cosmic microwave background temperature :formula: are related through the relation:
:formula: (14)
where :formula: stands for any non-adiabatic expansion due to en- tropy production. In standard cosmology, the instantaneous :formula: annihilation is assumed at :formula: The heating due to this annihilation is accounted by :formula: where :formula: for :formula: while :formula: for :formula:
In order to find constraints from primordial nucle- osythesis on power-law cosmology parameters, we utilize :formula: (age of the Universe) estimated by Komatsu et al. (2011) on the basis of 7 year data from WMAP and astrophysical data from other sources. Further, the model is assumed to have current temperature :formula: The primordial nucleosynthesis requires that :formula: :formula: This puts the following constraints on :formula: and :formula:
We observe that primordial nucleosynthesis requires de- celerating expansion :formula: of the Universe within the framework of power-law cosmology. This is contrary to out- come of accelerated expansion :formula: of the Universe ob- tained in earlier sections by using latest data sets of :formula: and SNe Ia observations. Also the primordial nucleosynthe- sis forces the Hubble constant :formula: which is much smaller than its values estimated in earlier :formula: by using the updated data sets of :formula: and SNe Ia This shows that the power-law cosmological models which suc- ceed in mimicking the nucleosynthesis scenario are in con- flict with the constraints obtained on power-law cosmology parameters by using the latest observational data from :formula: and SNe Ia. A similar conclusion on power-law cosmologies was drawn by Kaplinghat et al. (1999). However, in the case at hand, it has been done with updated observational data sets and the constraints have been obtained on both the parameters :formula: and :formula:
7 CONSTRAINTS ON STATEFINDERS IN POWER-LAW COSMOLOGY
The Hubble parameter :formula: and deceleration parameter :formula: are useful geometric parameters in cosmology, which describe the expansion history of the Universe. For instance, :formula: :formula: indicates an expanding Universe while :formula: characterizes an accelerated expansion of the Universe. In order to explain accelerated expansion

In Fig.5, the comparison of the derived best fit model based on :formula: with the observational 557 SNe Ia data points (shown with error bars) of Union2 compilation in the lo region 68.41 ≤ Ho ≤ :formula: is illustrated. We see that the model is in excellent agreement with the observational SNe Ia data.
6 CONSTRAINTS FROM PRIMORDIAL NUCLEOSYNTHESIS
Before we find constraints on power-law cosmology param- eters from primordial big bang nucleosynthesis (BBN), it is helpful to reproduce the brief review of the BBN in stan- dard model given by Kaplinghat et al. (1999). The neutron- proton ratio :formula: where :formula: is the neutron-proton mass difference, at high temperatures :formula: is maintained by charged-current weak inter- actions among neutrons, protons, electrons, positrons and neutrinos. When the Universe is of order 1 s old, :formula: MeV, the :formula: ratio "freezes out" due to the inequilibrium of weak interactions and free neutron decay with a lifetime of 887 s. At this stage the deuterium (D) produced due to

However, these models encounter degeneracy on the geometric parameters :formula: (involving first time derivative of scale factor) and :formula: (involving second time derivative of scale factor) at the present epoch (Malekjani &

Thus the geometric parameters :formula: and :formula: are not capable of discriminating between different dark energy models and a viable diagnostic tool is required for this purpose. Sahni et al. (b) Variation of :formula: versus q. The black dot represents the location of de Sitter (dS) point :formula: in the :formula: plane, and star symbol on the :formula: curve shows the position of :formula: and :formula: in the best fit model obtained from :formula: Ia data. In both panels, the vertical dashed line separates the acceleration and deceleration zones. The arrows show the direction of the evolution of trajectories as :formula: varies from 0.5 to -1. We observe that ACDM point :formula: or equivalently the dS point :formula: is an attractor in power-law cosmology.
ing between different dark energy models. The statefinders involve derivatives of scale factor upto third order and are defined as
:formula: :formula: and '
The remarkable feature of statefinders is that these pa- rameters depend on scale factor and its time derivatives, and hence are geometric in nature (Sahni 2002). Further, different dark energy models exhibit different evolutionary trajectories in the :formula: plane. Moreover, the well known flat ACDM model corresponds to the point :formula: and :formula: :formula: (Alam et al. 2003). These features of statefinders provide an opportunity to distinguish between different dark energy models. The statefinder diagnostic tool has been extensively used in the literature as a means to dis- tinguish between different dark energy models (see Alam et al. 2003; Ali et al. 2010; Malekjani & Khadom-Mohamaddi 2012 and references therein). In what follows, we test the power-law cosmology by statefinder diagnostic tool.
In power-law cosmology, the statefinders read as :formula: and

We immediately notice that :formula: and :formula: at :formula: Thus the the power-law cosmology mimics the ACDM model at :formula: We obtain the evolutionary :formula: and :formula: trajectories for the power-law cosmology as shown in Fig. 6 for the values of :formula: in the range :formula: . The black dot in the left panel (a) at :formula: represents the location of flat ACDM model while the the black dot in the right panel (b) shows the location of the de Sitter (dS) point :formula: The star symbol in both panels corresponds to the best fit model based on :formula: (z)+SNe Ia. It is interesting to note that the ACDM statefinder pair :formula: the dS point :formula: is an attractor in power-law
Now we find the constraints on the statefinders of power-law cosmology from :formula: SNe Ia and BBN ob- servations. The :formula: data constrain the statefinders as :formula: and :formula: while the SNe Ia data constraints on statefinders are :formula: and :formula: :formula: The joint test of :formula: and SNe Ia data puts the following constraints on statefinders: :formula: :formula: The errors in the above values are at :formula: level. The primordial nucleosynthesis restricts :formula: and :formula: We observe that the best fit values of statefinders :formula: and :formula: predicted by observational :formula: and SNe Ia data are in conflict with the ones estimated by BBN, as expected.
8 SUMMARY
In this paper, we have found the bounds on the parameters :formula: and :formula: of the power-law cosmology. The numerical results are summarized in Table 1.
Some key observations are as follows:
(i) The constraints on the deceleration parameter :formula: clearly indicate that the astronomical observations of :formula: and SNe Ia predict the cosmic acceleration within the framework of power-law cosmology. Thus, power-law cosmological models are viable for describing the observed accelerating nature of Universe.
(ii) We see that the estimates of Hubble constant in power- law cosmology are in close agreement with independent in- vestigations of :formula: carried out in literature (Freedman et al. 2001; Suyu et al. 2010; Jarosik et al. 2010; Riess et al. 2011; Beutler et al. 2011) as discussed in Section 1.
(iii) The derived best-fitting model fits well to the observa- tional data points from :formula: and SNe Ia observations (see Figs 4 and 5).

8 SUMMARY
In this paper, we have found the bounds on the parameters
:formula: and :formula: of the power-law cosmology. The numerical results
are summarized in Table 1.
Some key observations are as follows:
(i) The constraints on the deceleration parameter :formula: clearly
indicate that the astronomical observations of :formula: and SNe
Ia predict the cosmic acceleration within the framework of
power-law cosmology. Thus, power-law cosmological models
are viable for describing the observed accelerating nature of
Universe.
(ii) We see that the estimates of Hubble constant in power-
law cosmology are in close agreement with independent in-
vestigations of :formula: carried out in literature (Freedman et al.
2001; Suyu et al. 2010; Jarosik et al. 2010; Riess et al. 2011;
Beutler et al. 2011) as discussed in Section 1.
(iii) The derived best-fitting model fits well to the observa-
tional data points from :formula: and SNe Ia observations (see
Figs 4 and 5).

The former one tells us the expansion rate of the Universe today while the latter one characterizes the accelerating :formula: or decel- erating :formula: nature of the Universe. In the recent past, there have been numerous attempts to estimate the value of :formula: Freedman et al. A recent estimate of the Hubble constant, which used a new infrared camera on the HST to measure the distance and redshift for a collection of astronomical objects, gives a value of :formula: (Riess et al. 2011). An alter- native probe using data from galactic clusters gave a value of :formula: (Beutler et al. 2011).

In this paper, we show that the power-law cosmology essentially depends on the parameters :formula: and :formula: We intend to find the observational constraints on the power-law cos- mology parameters using the recent observational data from :formula: and supernova observations. We also intend to test the power-law cosmology with primordial nucleosynthesis. The paper is organized as follows: The basic equations of power- law cosmology are introduced in Section 2. Section 3 deals with the constraints on the parameters :formula: and :formula: from the latest :formula: data while Section 4 is devoted to find the con- straints using Union2 compilation of 557 SNe Ia data points. In Section 5, we perform the joint test using :formula: and SNe Ia data. Section 6 deals with the constraints on power-law cosmology from primordial nucleosynthesis while Section 7 is devoted to study the statefinders in power-law cosmology. In the last Section, we summarize the main results of the paper.
We study a general class of power-law cosmology described by the dimensionless scale factor

collision of neutrons and protons is rapidly photodissoci- ated by the cosmic background photons. This causes very low abundance of :formula: and thus heavier nuclei are not formed at this epoch. Thus nucleosynthesis is delayed by this "pho- todissociation bottleneck". However, when the universe is ~ 3 minutes old, the temperature falls below ~ 80 keV, the deuterium bottleneck is broken. At this stage the nuclear reactions quickly burn out the remaining free neutrons into 4He and leave trace amounts of D, 3He and :formula: (Walker et al. 1991). A viable cosmological model must mimic the above scenario for proper synthesis of the light elements in the early Universe. In the following, we test the power-law cosmological model for primordial nucleosynthesis.

We observe that primordial nucleosynthesis requires de- celerating expansion :formula: of the Universe within the framework of power-law cosmology. This is contrary to out- come of accelerated expansion :formula: of the Universe ob- tained in earlier sections by using latest data sets of :formula: and SNe Ia observations. Also the primordial nucleosynthe- sis forces the Hubble constant :formula: which is much smaller than its values estimated in earlier :formula: by using the updated data sets of :formula: and SNe Ia This shows that the power-law cosmological models which suc- ceed in mimicking the nucleosynthesis scenario are in con- flict with the constraints obtained on power-law cosmology parameters by using the latest observational data from :formula: and SNe Ia. A similar conclusion on power-law cosmologies was drawn by Kaplinghat et al. (1999). However, in the case at hand, it has been done with updated observational data sets and the constraints have been obtained on both the parameters :formula: and :formula:
7 CONSTRAINTS ON STATEFINDERS IN POWER-LAW COSMOLOGY

The Hubble parameter :formula: and deceleration parameter :formula: are useful geometric parameters in cosmology, which describe the expansion history of the Universe. For instance, :formula: :formula: indicates an expanding Universe while :formula: characterizes an accelerated expansion of the Universe. In order to explain accelerated expansion

The remarkable feature of statefinders is that these pa- rameters depend on scale factor and its time derivatives, and hence are geometric in nature (Sahni 2002). Further, different dark energy models exhibit different evolutionary trajectories in the :formula: plane. Moreover, the well known flat ACDM model corresponds to the point :formula: and :formula: :formula: (Alam et al. 2003). These features of statefinders provide an opportunity to distinguish between different dark energy models. In this paper, we have found the bounds on the parameters :formula: and :formula: of the power-law cosmology. The numerical results are summarized in Table 1.
Some key observations are as follows:

(i) The constraints on the deceleration parameter :formula: clearly indicate that the astronomical observations of :formula: and SNe Ia predict the cosmic acceleration within the framework of power-law cosmology. Thus, power-law cosmological models are viable for describing the observed accelerating nature of Universe.

(ii) We see that the estimates of Hubble constant in power- law cosmology are in close agreement with independent in- vestigations of :formula: carried out in literature (Freedman et al. 2001; Suyu et al. 2010; Jarosik et al. 2010; Riess et al. 2011; Beutler et al. 2011) as discussed in Section 1.
(iii) The derived best-fitting model fits well to the observa- tional data points from :formula: and SNe Ia observations (see Figs 4 and 5).
